-- 3rd seed with 1GW5 + 1,5vp in final

Deck Name : Royal with Cheese
Description : A deck built around the cheese-shaped discipline (Protean) and votes, hence the deck name. The deck relies on very versatile cards and is able to adapt to many situations.
It is a bit slow to build up, but it is not necessarily a bad thing as you don't want to be the bad guy too early. The deck has some hand jam problems, another Heart of Nizchetus could help.
Also, I spent 3 rounds wondering why I wasn't drawing any Pentex Subversion. I really don't know why there is not any in this deck.

Crypt (12 cards, min=33, max=44, avg=9.92)
------------------------------------------
4x Adana de Sforza	 11  CEL OBF POT PRE PRO aus	inner circle	Brujah:4
3x Hardestadt		 11  DOM FOR POT PRE cel pro	inner circle	Ventrue:4
3x Aksinya Daclau	 9   ANI FOR PRE PRO cel tha			Gangrel antitribu:4
1x Malabranca		 9   AUS CEL PRE PRO obf	archbishop	Toreador antitribu:4
1x André the Manipulator 6   FOR PRO					Gangrel:5

// Adana is the real star of the deck because she has everything needed. You must be careful with Hardestadt until he gets his Protean skill because he has access to 9 less S:CE.
// Aksinya helps surviving bleed decks and cycles the extra Zillah's Valley or Wider View you may draw. André is very nice when you can't afford another high-cap vampire,
// or if you can afford him in extra, and a 10 hand size (with the Monastery) is awesome.

Deck Name: !Ventrue Toolbox
Description:
The classic !Ventrue grinder, but geared towards Under Siege. Fortitude to
deal with the occasional nasty combat deck, bounce for bleed or blocking,
and some permacept to wear down stealth decks. I chose to focus on using
more Governs over pool recursion in order to reliably get out more minions
and also have extra bleed. The Govern chain is optimized for multiple
Governs at DOM per turn, situation permitting.

-- 3vp in final

Deck Name: Mal's Wall of Fatties
Description: Use Malgorzata's special to get the Capuchin out, then Lord Tremere, wall up and make them obey. Use Magics to get the Capuchin the Erebus Mask, get somebody the Bowl of Convergence or Signet of King Saul if you need it and Heart of Nizchetus if not. Get a Sniper Rifle if there are big caps out there (since they don't obey). Block and bounce carefully. Act recklessly only if you have Mirror Walk in hand. Bloat as needed, tool up, and bleed/vote your prey to death. Allies are bad (they don't obey either), but there are two Far Mastery's, at least, and you have a 9 card hand (or more when you have a Dreams or the Monastery). Lord Tremere gives Mal an extra action and so do Rutor's Hands. Dedicated rush combat is obviously your biggest threat (though the Obediences stop that too as long as they are in your hand and it isn't Enkidu or another 11-cap rusher). I actually had a multi-rush Lazverinus, Thrall of Lambach, deck as my predator in the first round, but he was so busy rushing his stealth bleed predator and grand predator (after his predator was ousted), that he never had a chance to rush me. I actually bled out my prey (when it was down to the two of us) one second before the game timed out. Fun times.

-- 3vp in final

Deck Name: Big Gangrel
Description:
My Gangrel IC deck has been a staple for a long time. My recent update was
influenced by Martin Weinmayer's NAC deck. Your kill combo is Parity Shift +
Govern the Unaligned + Conditioning. Several fun tricks in the deck. First game
in the tournament, my predator was a power bleed deck. He Pentex Subversioned
my first vampire and then hit me for multiple bleeds for 5. He got me down to 2
pool before I came back to take all the VPs and the Game Win. This deck
survives way better than I expected with considerable pool gain. In the Finals,
I got to choose my predator and prey which gave me an overwhelming advantage.
The deck is a little too dependent on strike: combat ends and I will probably
add a Secure Haven.

Notes:
  Jake Washington	         - The Combo is with Vessel, but generic blood gain is good.
  Metro Underground	      - Fun with Enkil Cog but good after bleeding to setup bleed bounce.
  Pentex Subversion	      - Not great, because you never want to block the (D) action.
  Perfectionist	         - Free Govern the Unaligned.
  Zoo Hunting Ground	      - Two hunting grounds in play is very nice.
  Carlton Van Wyk          - One of your best defense cards against Combat rush.
  Form of Mist	            - My ratio of combat cards is something I stole from Martin W.
  Heart of Nizchetus	      - Good, but not necessary.
  Seal of Veddartha	      - Better than the Heart.
  Scourge of the Enochians - played but never mattered.
  Banishment	            - This gets rid of problems and can cause more pool loss than parity shift.
  Guard Dogs	            - Fun with Enkil Cog, can get you to long range, and works with bounce.

Deck Name: Necrospace
Description:
For the best results, alter mustache to all vampires. All of them.
The most important thing (after mustache) playing this deck is to not die.
Storage Annex just isn't worth it. Extra hand size isn't an effect, it's just utility, and should be taken as such.
Charigger is pretty nifty if you're seated next to another Nocturne deck, but that's not often. Could be something else.
Shroud of Night is good, but should probably be a third piece of Spectral Divination and Shroud of Absence - that it can't be used in bleeds is pretty devastating after all.
Even with so much boring dominate, it's actually a lot of fun to play!

-- 2GW7 + 4vp in final

Deck Name: Matasuntha & Enkidu, a true bromance.
Description:
Bring out Matasuntha asap and play a passive wall early and mid game, keep a low profile.
Block strategically, try to totally destroy at least 1 vampire of your predator as deterrent.
Bleed with Matasuntha when you can, he doesn't need to stay untapped.
When your prey's vampires are all in torpor, bring out a small cap vamp/imbued to bleed.
Bring out Enkidu for the end game, if you bring him out too early, you lose your low profile and become a serious table threat.
Pool gain is slow, but defense is stable as long as you have Matasuntha ready, helps with keeping a low profile.
Table talk only when needed and don't be too aggressive in table talk, we're keeping a low profile.

Deck Name : Farley Mowat
Created by: Darby Keeney, original design though not unlike Roberto Venturi's 2011 entry in the TWDA.

Finals seating : Saulot Hide the Heart (Faye, 4th) --> Scobax (Kelly, 1st) --> Khazar (Darby, 2nd) --> Turbo Baron (Fletcher, 5th) --> Daughers Lily Prelude (Raj, 3rd).

An immediate Pentex and bad opening draw shafted the Baron, gaining both Khazar's and Lily Prelude momentum for early VPs - also importantly removing one of the 2 decks that would re-actively screw with minion actions/blood totals.

The game devolved into never-ending Scobax vs lots of actions from 2 players. The Daughters were 1 turn from being ousted pretty much the whole endgame but I had no intention seeing Raj below 6 pool until a few Wraiths reached play or Kelly was ousted. Kelly felt it necessary to Scobax every Wraith attempt, so I was happy to fully occupy his attention and allow Raj's votes to keep Kelly in a defensive bloat/block posture - even when Charming Lobbies hit the table.

The Khazar's deck ended with with no Embraces, no Wraiths, a prey with no library and 5 pool, but holding 1.5 VP for the game win from 2nd seed. A postmortem suggested reversing my position with Kelly's might improved his situation, or that opting to bleed (hard) immediately on entering the 3 player game might have yielded a different result. Either way, I felt this was a very well--played final from all involved and enjoyed the game completely.

--  3vp in final
Description:

Final table: Marko (Lasombra Wormwood Baltimorepurge Toolbox) ->
             Ilari (Giovanni Powerbleed) ->
	     Jukka (Dementation Anarch stealth bleed) ->
	     Jyri (Blackhand Dementation Bleed with Anu Diptinatpa ->
	     Lauri (me) (Lord Tremere Toolbox)


This was first tournament arrange in one of our new players (Tero Aalto, he
started playing last march, but was already playing at the EC in Genoa) home at
Töölö, Helsinki. Nice residence and works for a small tournaments, with 2-3
tables top. We got 11 players turning up, but one opted to leave before the
start and see the new Star Wars instead, so Thanks to HG for that. We played
two rounds and Final then with 10 players.

Preliminary rounds only had 1 GW, in those four games, and that was by Jukka
with 2vp eventhough he was ousted in that game, so all the tables went Time.
Marko won his place in final by coin toss (dice roll) over Henna-Riikka(one of
the two tournament first timers). And Jyri won third seed agianst me in coin
toss (dice Roll). Ilari was second seed (another tournament first timer) and
Jukka with only GW of course was the first seed.

So me and Marko sat at the table, and Jyri opted to bleed me, then Ilari opted
to bleed Jyri and finaly Jukka went between Ilari and Jyri. Marko was diced to
be the starter.

I had personally really bad start and didn’t get Malgorzata on starting crypt,
and actually opted to buy new vampire twice before even getting her, and well
so it was turn 5 when I finaly got my first vampire, everyone else had 3-5
minions by that time, and my predator had bled me twice by bleeds of four, so I
really didn’t expect to win.

However my predator got enough pressure by his predator that I manage to get
Malgorzata up and villein, then start using her special ability to bring Lord
Tremere up and villein him too, even with Wormwood by my prey lowering capacity
down to 7-8.

Even then the Giovanni with four vampires including Le Dinh Tho, manage to oust
his prey and even next one, while my prey with the Lasombra gave a little
pressure to him, finaly allowing me to do timely oust with bleeds and Anarchist
Uprising.

If I had not manage to oust Marko then, I propably would not have survived his
and Ilaris turn, but with that timely oust, I did have the upper hand, and
manage to put all of Ilaris vampires into Torpor and win the came about 10
minutes before time, earning me Tournament win, and my first TWDA entry without
Nana Buruku featured in my decklist.

Winners decklist:

This deck is similar to EC Genoa winners Pau Vilars, so thanks to him and others who had played similar decks before

-- 5vp in final

Deck Name : What We Do In the Shadows
Description : Black Hand tap-and-bleed. In this tournament, I rarely drew any of the tapping tech (except Nocturn Theater, but see below), and so it ended up playing as bleed-and-bleed instead. I got 13 of the 14 possible VPs available to me, though, so I can't complain too much.

Theoretically good tech which I didn't get to use includes using Tattoo Signal and the bleed equipment to do some light Darby Dancing, using Tangle Atropos' Hand with the bleed equipment to safely eliminate bleed bounce and then bleed again with the same vampire, and being able to boast that you played a Lasombra bleed deck without ever adding stealth to a bleed action.

Thanks to Darby and Hugh for transcontinental and trans-Atlantic deck advice, to Karl Schaefer for lending me the Shrouds of Absence, and to Mark Loughman for breaking down the local metagame before the tournament.

-- 3vp in final

Deck Name: Barrenness Twister
Description: Deck has 24 burn option cards out of 66 library cards. Burn the burn option cards to cull your deck until you get combinations set up, then use Ashur Tablets to put the burned cards back in the deck once you have your Maleficias in place. Best play in finals was using The Unnamed and two Hordes, each with 1 Maleficia on them, to put three Barrenness cards on my prey's Scout Youngwood and then burn her by playing Scourge. Ouch. Other than the Maleficia cards (which are very strong), it's a typical Unnamed deck - Enkil Cog The Unnamed, bleed on your turn, bleed on someone else's turn. This deck generates mucho table hate.

Deck Name : [2016 Origins] Six Demon Bag
Description : Deceivingly robust unnamed bleed deck. Plinks away while maintaining a decent pool buffer, then tends to have unexpectedly large turns (often with a pair of Infernal Servitors back-to-back). I'm still shocked at how well this deck holds up in tournament play.
Finalists: Mark Loughman (Lasombra Nocturn Bleed) --> Sonam Adinolf (Spirit Marionette + DOM Tap/Bleed) --> Will Kristoff (Alonzo Petrodon Toolbox) --> Adam Hulse (Ishtarri Multiaction) -- Darby Keeney (unnamed Bleed)

If one wanted to make modifications to the library, the Coven would be a very worthwhile inclusion and 1-2 Forms of Mist might be worth considering. Other than that, it seems to handle pretty consistently..

Deck Name : The Crypt That Should Not Be
Description : Little bit of this, little bit of that leveraging a crypt that I've previously suggested might be reasonably strong. A good case could be made for running Gustaphe as the sole lead, but I wanted one minion with both +1 bleed and [OBF].

This version is vulnerable against political decks, but fairly well rounded otherwise. It is entirely coincidence that the number of actions, modifiers, masters and combat cards are pretty much equivalent. These ratios just seemed to flow correctly in casual playtesting.

Again very nice attendance, we decided before tournament to play only 2 rounds and Final. Very nice weather out and Finland was playing WC Ice Hockey semi-finals agaisnt Russia, so with just 10 players we took just 2 preliminary rounds and then finals.

The finals started that I (Lauri) played crosstable banishment on Muaziz and then nxt turn Chameleon steal on it, to get the table threat of that basically ruined my game on second round, luckily I did get to the finals with just 2vps from first round, though with dice against Matti, who had same vps and also same tp. As fifth seed I had to go aggressively after that ahead, but Teemu managed to oust both me and Jari on same turn after he had already ousted Mikko, rather easy prey without Muaziz. and won the tournament then with his 3 vps. Congrats to Teemu for returning from torpor and again winning tournament..

-- 5vp in final

Deck Name: Saulot and Nergal: Beauty and the Beast
Created by: Mark Jasper (modified version of deck created by Roberto Mautone, Jr.)

Final table: David Corson-Knowles (Weenie Potence Thrown Gate) > Kate Hanley (Malk 94) > Brett Schofield (Ventrue Anti Obtenebration Vote) > Mark Jasper (Nergal, Saulot and the Great Beast) > Ian Lee (Mid-cap Assamite toolbox?)
Tipping Point: The turn after ousting Ian about 1 hour in I had 3 pool, Unleash Hell's Fury in play,
Saulot with 1 blood and Repulsion, merged Nergal with 3 blood and Call the Great Beast on him already.
Brett (my predator) had 3 ready titled !Ventrue with obtenebration, vote lock and would surely have ousted me
on his next turn. Dave had 10 pool, 3 tapped weenies (3-5 caps), Carlton untapped and Fame on his prey's vamp
in torpor (Kate had 4-6 pool and Gilbert Duane untapped). After paying 1 pool for Fame and 1 to untap Nergal,
I had 1 pool left. I had Nergal bleed for 3, using his ADV special and the only stealth card in my hand (Mirror Walk)
to get past Carlton. Freak drive. Top decked a Gift of Sleep replacing Freak Drive! Then Saulot Spirit Marionette
bled for 3 with just enough stealth (the Gift of Sleep from hand, repulsion on Saulot) to get past Carlton
and tap him. I had only one Mirror Walk left in my hand, so without the tapping component of Spirit Marionette,
The Great Beast couldn't get past Carlton. Then I popped the Beast on Nergal and bled for 3 to get him to 1.
Dave's own Fame finished him off. With Dave ousted, I had no more fear of getting rushed to death. I had just
enough pool (Brett pressured me hard with KRCs and bounced bleeds from Kate at me the whole game) and the Fury
left to survive another turn of KRCs from Brett and another bounced bleed for 6 from Kate (she stealthed it
by the Fury), to oust Kate and then Brett soon after, completing the table sweep. This was after getting
only 1.5 VP in the preliminary rounds and just barely making the final table as the 5th seed. Incredibly
close tournament and my first win!!

-- 2vp in final, win by highest seed

Deck Name : Princess Pitch
Description : After going back and forth between versions with or without Dominate, with or without Villein+Perfectionist,
I finally tried the highly aggressive way of doing things: no deflection, 2 more Shattering Crescendos and Daring the Dawn
to ensure the delivery. The deck is a bit like a weenie potence when having an aggressive predator, but with
even less defense considering the intercept problems of the Daughters. Backousting IS an option because there is
very little pool gain (Legal, Wider View and Powerbase if you're lucky to draw it).
The "stealth" module (Daring the Dawn, Missing Voice, Siren's Lure, Paris Opera House and Virtuosa) works extremely well,
even against heavy blocker. Just be sure to use the Daring wisely so you send the blocking minions to torpor.

October 24th 2015
3R+F

Jonathan van der Smissen

Deck Name:[KIA] Kiasyd 66 cards

The deck is just big enough to get you through the table.
1st game: 3vp. My third vp was just when I decked out with 6 minutes left on the clock. Most of my minions were torpored, witouth cards my last one soon joined them and all 4 got eaten.
2nd game: 0vp. Beast rush deck in my back. My deck can't cope with rush potence torn grapple blur.
3rd game: 3vp. a crucial seduction on anneke allowed my first oust. My prey and predator were contesting a pentex for the whole game. Martin's presence bleeder got through the wakes of anneke anson after which I took the table.

Final: setite corrupt vote -> nosferatu vote -> gangrel royalty -> me kiasyd sb -> presence bleed.
My opening crypt at this table was perfect. I had pheridima(8 bishop) and omme (7 priscus) 4 transfers to start with and a govern.
Me and the nosferatu had votelock over my predator which allowed me to keep the gangrel alive but severely damaged and a little threat. I got through the presence deck, at which point the table started to collapse. The nosferatu died soon after. Giving me, the stealth bleed deck votelock over the table. I went from 14 to 4 pool in a single turn, allowing myself to get parity shifted for my predators benefit, pentexing xaviar(who downgraded to prince) influencing a new minion and paying pheridima to get an untapped minion.

I delayed the reckless agitation from the setites who were about to backoust me.
Then my predator did a bleed of 1 with form of mist (3 pool left) he tried to cycle hard to find his kine resources contested , luckily he failed to find it.
My prey had 3 pool left, my predator 7.
My prey bounces the first govern, bounces the second govern. I go for a third and luckily that's all he had. Bleed for 1 with a seduction to win the game.

EC 2015 - Last Chance Qualifier
Warsaw, Poland
August 28th 2015
74 players
Otso Saariluoma

Description:
I believe this is the list I won Last Chance with. Maybe someone from the EC organizers can check that the
tournament details and the decklist are correct (as I already disassembled the deck back in the EC and
there's no list other than the one I gave to judges)?

The deck itself has the usual suspects with AUS PRE. It is inspired by a similiar deck popularized by
Martin Weinmeyer's EC win back in 2009 - although with higher caps, more auspex and lacking fortitude and
Daring the Dawns. This version has problems with dedicated blockers and stealth vote, but otherwise has
proven to be quite resilient with lots of reactions and combat ends, which gives the flexibility to alter
your tempo and possibly wait for an opportunity to present itself.

In the preliminary rounds I really would have needed Darings against my ani pro prey. In the second round
I got lucky as Kim was one card short of running away with the game, which would have costed me the spot
in the finals. And I got lucky again in the finals drawing half of my combat ends in the first quarter of
the library against Pascal's Enkidu - but some luck is obviously needed in this game. In the heads-up
against Noora's Unnamed the deck transformed into a half-decent block deck.

Description: The event turned out to be a very nice one, with many players attending (for current standards) thanks to a big Italian delegation, who came, saw, and conquered
The final was a quick and dirty affair, with Martin's fearsome Dracon deck quickly annihilated by a Saturday Night Special / Dragon Breath Rounds combo pulled out by Bram.

Deck Name : The feel of the rod
Description : Based on David Durans "I Have a Stick" from Camarilla Conclave 2014. I wanted to play princes with sticks, but not my usual one, so I took David's deck and made some random tweaks. I switched 2 Vessel for 2 Villein, 4 Public Trust for Governs, 1 Parity Shift for 1 Anarchist Uprising, 1 Foreshadowing for 1 Conditioning, 2 Redirection for 2 Deflectioning, 2 WWEF for 2 Second Traditions, 4 Taste of Vitae for 2 Soak and 2 Weighted Walking Stick. Switched Joseph D for extra Mustafa. I see now that the alternations can be discussed, and there are still much room for improvement, but it worked out fine at the tournament :)

Deck Name : Payload
Description : This deck originally had one Monastery of Shadows, but I must have moved it to another deck or something. Basically what you have here is an Edward Vignes deck where everybody costs 4 extra pool. The nice thing about all those titles is you can try to shut down bloat vote. Adding pool to the table is bad. I made this deck because I hadn't won a tournament with Ventrue yet (never had an Arika phase) and because I've lost my fear of being ousted and now just play a lot of offense. Haven't had a game go to time in quite a while.

Anyway, the deck took 15 of 19 potential VPs all day, which might be a personal best. I let two get away in the first round because Peteo used some kind of mind control on me and convinced me he had wakes when he didn't. I then took 4 VPs on a pair of 5 player tables and swept the final, mostly by letting bad things happen to people who weren't me. All three of my preliminary rounds finished first and the final took around an hour.

Lex Pike wins the gold star for putting Funeral Wake into the TWDA in a tournament by the same name! I don't know if that has ever been done before, especially within days of the cards becoming tournament legal.

Also new to the TWDA: Enzo Adv, Soul Feasting

Deck Name: Giovanni mini powerbleed with goods.

Comments:
Giovanni is one of my favorite clans. A little bits of goods for different things. Been playing the “Shroud Mastery” angle a bit. Shroud Mastery Card is cool, but not good enough in the sense that it becomes a dead card in your hand if you do not have a wraith card in your hand or in play. Toolboxish mini powerbleed with some vote defense tech.

Wish there is another stealth package, maybe anarch rail road tech. I keep having visions of one card vs my stealth package like the Bowl of Convergence, Eyes of Argus, ect…would stop/slow down this deck.
Do need to remove/replace Talbot's Chainsaw - all three rounds Ambrosius or Tye Cooper either got stolen or destroyed. I did have the pleasure to see Ambrosius got Pentex Subversion for the first time.

Description: It's a vote deck with a lot of toolbox, defense, and agg strikes.
Notes:
I originally had built a tournament-level Terrifisto deck, and I also had a
Lambach deck in my casual deck supply (which used goofy stuff like Deploy the Hand).
I played the Terrifisto deck at the LCQ #1, and I found it to be quite
underwhelming. So I started a deck retrofit the morning of the tournament,
using the Lambach crypt, and the Terrifisto library. Removing ~8 fortitude cards from
the Terrifisto deck gave me some creative space to work with.

Minion text offers on-demand bleed and Orlando almost ensures votelock,
so the deck is often able make opportunistic moves.

The finals saw 4 of the 5 players in potentially winning positions as the clock wore down.
This created incentive for an unusual number of cross-table rescues, allowing me to survive
Hugh's relentless Ahrimane and Ossian rushing. I got a lucky VP in the end for a win as high seed.

Deck Name: Just Say NO
Created By: Stefan Ferenci, slightly modified by Miguel A. Ripoll
Description: I wanted to remember old times, so I tried to keep the deck as similar
as possible with Stefan's deck to see how it could work nowadays (the only additions
are Eyes of Argus and Read the Winds). In this deck, you should almost never use
Eyes of Argus for intercept, but as extra untaps. The deck has some problems, mainly
it's very master heavy, and lacks permanent intercept. Sometimes it's difficult to
combine Breath of the Dragon and they can clog your hand. But it is still a sturdy deck,
good against fatties and with enough ousting power.

Deck Name: Khazar's Diary deck ripped from TWDA
Created by: Not Chris Shorb
Description:
Played at the San Jose Qualifier Dec 28, 2013.
I discarded Sudario without ever playing it. For my playstyle, I couldn't
ever see discarding 3 cards from my hand at random...
I'd probably sub in 1 Call Hungry Dead, 1 Shroudsight, 1 Shroud Mastery,
2 Spiritual Intervention. But that's because I'm a toolbox-head at heart.
Khazar's never kicked off - sitting between two wall decks my first game and
one of the 2 walls again my 2nd game hosed me pretty hard.
Anarch Converts saved me in both preliminary games - one of the walls was using
Anarch Revolt to do pool damage...

Finals - I used my predator's lunge to deflect to my prey and wear his defenses down.
A Pentex on his remaining vampire allowed me to oust. We timed out 2 minutes 15 seconds
later. That gave me the only VP at the table...

Deck Name: The Quiet Achiever 2013
Description: A 2013 incarnation of the deck I used to
win the 2005 Australian Championships.  This deck never
seems to do much, but is very effective. Table play is
critical, especially early on. Most VP's scored by "lunging"
(with Pentex Subversion) or by combat late in the game. Very
difficult to oust, especially if allowed to set up. The absolute
key is to use Magic of the Smith to bring out the Heart as
early in the game as possible. From there you have most tables
covered.

Deck name: 419 911
Since most of the times your prey and grandprey make deals for bleeds of one
and it's impossible to eagle's sight everything, I thought it might be worthwhile
to try and prevent your prey from playing at all ... so brainwash, pentex for something
that comes out, a bit of defense and an occasional eagle's sight. Ashur to recover
removed 419, intercept and the small amount of combat. And a last stand that I pulled
off to play in the second game, so your grandprey doesn't get the pool you have on the 419s.

Deck Name: Guillaume for rent
Created By: thelonius_reloaded
Description: It's a toolbox recursive deck, with some situational strong
defense and a light necrobleed module to oust.  Extremely valuable had been
the 2 Trochomancy to take care of other recursive decks, and the combo
Revelations/Precision to get rid of a double Deflection in my prey's hand.
Sacre Coeur never been much useful due to the lack of ally deck, but I will
keep it.  Nicomedes is AMAZING when you have 11/12 cards in hand, and
Sennadurek skill has often been underestimated, giving me full acces to
almost all table's hand.

Deck Name: Guedado Ghouls
Description: This deck is designed to bring out War Ghouls at extra
speed - cutting the deck size to 50 and using D'habi revenants does
the trick nicely, plus the revenants make perfect "meat" for corrupt
constructs later on. Ideally you should have 3-4 minions on turn 3,
which is not uncommon. Guedado is a true star here, giving you access
to the Powerbase, Forgotten Labyrinths and of course the Strange day,
which literally saved the day many times.  Some credit goes to Szewski
for his advices before playing my 1st tournament with this deck. Thanks mate.

Deck Name: Imbued nerds no longer worship Satan
Description: I've been playing variations of this same deck
since my 2007 "Twist with Conviction".

Tournaments are Serious Business, so my Imbued have ditched
their wacky infernal friends (with their Maleficia/Evil Eye
or Striga/Scobax module).  They still love to hack computers
though, since that seriously speeds up their stealth bleeding.

Things I would change:
- Remove all but one On the Qui Vive.
- Wendell Delburton was useless. I forgot to take him out
after reducing the number of Weighted Walking Sticks by a lot.
- Suddens or Washes would be nice.

Winner of the German ECQ 2013. So far I have played this deck for 6 games.
3 Game Wins and some VPs in the other games. Seems pretty solid deck
construction to me and the cards are very balanced. Miller is important
but not a key vampire that you have to rely uopn.

Fleetness are great in combination with Palla Grande. Always had enough
forward pressure. Art Scams were extremelly important for blood gain and
saved me a lot of times.

Deck Name: Angelica Ascendant
Description: It won a tournament, but can it win a game?
Angelica's special means that Ascendances can be used for
intercept as well as pool gain. She gets Eternal Vigilance
and a .44 Magnum and blocks. Anson provides support, cycling
masters faster and providing Angelica with blood from the
Fifth Tradition. Fish for weenies, stealth bleed or bruise
bleed for the VP.

I felt perpetually short on bleed during the tournament,
and after having written out the decklist, I see that I
had fewer bleed cards than I thought. At minimum, one
Shroud of Night should be switched for a Threats. One of
the Ascendances probably should be changed to a Pentex
Subversion for contesting or lunging, but Pentex is less
prevalent in L.A. than in other places.

I got 1GW 7VP in the preliminary rounds and 3VP
in the final. The key to the final was to sit away
from the aus-weenies and to start moving forwards at
the right moment, ie. when I could oust my prey and
the aus-weenies in one turn.
I've had this deck assembled since Twilight Rebellion
came out. It's been tweaked and played every once in
a while, and at the moment I'm pretty happy with it.

2R+F

Dennis Lien

Deck Name: Extremely Silent and Incredibly Far Away
Description:
This is a modification of an old deck idea where I tried to have
Tariq "atone" and block everything.  This version is much more
balanced and simply tries to use Tariq's abilities with the possiblity
of an Atonement.  I can already see a few flaws in the design.
I think I'll dump the Necromancy and Anima Gathering angles and
just put in more reactions and action mods.

I was very fortunate to win the tourney.  It was a really fun final
and very competitive.  David Anderson as my prey looked like he had
it until Brett "archoned" his Mu-aziz.  I lost Tariq to Brett's Carlton
but was able to bleed out David with what I had left and hold on until
the game timed out.

Deck Name: Enkidu PRO CEL
Description:
I got some inspiration from Aleksi Nuora's TWD to build this one.

(thanks to my patient victims) and I'm quite happy about it.

1x T.J.		    3	cel for			 Gangrel:4
1x Clifton Derrik   2	cel			 Brujah:4
1x Leo Washington   2	cel pro			 Gangrel antitribu:4
1x Sean Andrews	    2	cel			 Toreador:4
1x Iris Bennett	    1	pro			 Caitiff:5

Library (90)
Action [8]
1x Aranthebes, The Immortal /* as always, to contest or to give me some
protection against weenie decks (or even intercept... it's a great card) */
1x Bum's Rush
1x Deep Song
1x Heroic Might -- makes some combat easier, but is not vital
2x Rumble
1x Sense Death
1x Taunt the Caged Beast

Action Modifier [2]
2x Enkil Cog /* allows permanent multirush and can give the edge
during's your predator's turn. The +1 bleed is great also.
Really a key card. */

Combat [59]
3x Canine Horde /* why play Drawing when you can get rid of that
Ivory Bow/.44 Magnum or Heart of Nizchetus? */
3x Claws of the Dead /* should always be used to burn vampires.
Can get rid of Ponticulus/Tye/Ambrosius */
9x Earth Meld /* defensive, untap, works well with Psyche! and
is free. Can't ask more */
2x Flesh of Marble -- cycles easily, handles War Ghoul/Carrion/.44 blur etc.
16x Psyche! -- key card, even 16 are sometimes not enough
11x Pursuit
2x Skin of Steel
4x Stutter-Step -- saves slots, can be used by the sidekicks to dodge
9x Taste of Vitae

Equipment [1]
1x Gran Madre di Dio, Italy -- against Tupdogs, Nocturns...

Master [12]
4x Blood Doll -- slow pool gain and blood management to feed Enkidu.
1x Guardian Angel -- the permanent "prevent 1" is a real life saver.
1x Monster -- permanent untap
1x Pentex(TM) Subversion /* for contest or to lock an annoying minion
(Ponticulus or the guy with the gun). Can also slow down your
predator when you don't have Enkidu yet) */
2x Sudden Reversal -- To be kept against Pentex, Temptation of Greater Power etc.
3x Wider View

Master come quite quickly because you cycle lots of cards. You can even
jam with master even there are only 12 of them, but it's quite rare.

Reaction [6]
6x Sense the Savage Way /* to block of course, but protects also
against Rötschreck/Mind Numb/Sensory Deprivation */

Retainer [2]
1x Homunculus -- not vital, but useful once you have Enkil Cog
1x Raven Spy -- helpful, but not vital.

Deck Name: Enkidu PRO CEL
Description:
I got some inspiration from Aleksi Nuora's TWD to build this one.
Protean and Celerity are great costless polyvalent combat
disciplines (there are only 3 Claws that cost blood amongst
the 60 combat cards). I playtested and tweaked it lots of
time during our weekly session (thanks to my patient victims)
and I'm quite happy about it.

predator when you don't have Enkidu yet) */

Summon the Abyss
San Jose, California
June 30th 2012
2R+F
20 players
Brett Schofield

Deck Name: Third Party Politics - Velya for President
Description:
A somewhat traditional "tap and cap" deck backed up with
the stealth offered by Vicissitude. I was pretty fortunate
in that I didn't face a real wall deck, and I was the only
political deck in the finals. But it is pretty ridiculous
how much pool this deck can acquire.

Crypt Selection: Velya and Lambach are the stars. Obviously
it is best for Velya to use Voter Cap, but refilling Lambach
for future Minion Taps is pretty good. I think there are a
couple of modifications that could be made to this deck.
More copies of Sascha Vykos (adv) could be added - she has
an amazingly good ability, but it is frustrating that she
can't use Mind of the Wilds for stealth. Sames goes for
Matteus, Flesh Sculptor (!Toreador) who could replace Meshenka.

Library: Over all, I was pleased with the amount of defense
(combat and bounce), stealth, and vote push this deck packs.
I only saw early crypt acceleration in one game, but it seems
hard to justify adding any more. On hind sight, I would
definitely drop the Crusade. I was surprised how often I
ended using Changeling to bleed.

Deck Name: Animal Trackers
Description: This was a rather old deck that had been updated
with newer cards for kicks. I hardly played it, however, because
of the popularity of animalism. When the tournament was about to
begin all of my decks were kind of in pieces, so I grabbed this one
- miscounted how many cards were in it (should have left it as
it was) - and proceeded to add in 4 Ashur's and an HoN. Well,
3 of the Tablets and an Anton (there were 4 originally) fell
under a table. I noticed the crypt shortage and tossed in another
Taylor from a different deck but did not notice the fallen Lbrary
cards, thankfully, since that would have made it 92 cards and
illegal. I did have to contend with one useless Ashur's and a
card ratio I would want to tweak but the deck drew well all
tournament. It is focused on dealing with S:CE and did a
commendable job. Anton and The Taylor came out every round
and at least one other, would change it to 4 and 4 and add
another Wider View or 2.

EC 2011 - First Chance Qualifier
Warsaw, Poland
November 13th 2011
3R+F
120 players
Djordje Bjelajac

Deck Name: Nobody expects the Shattering Crescendo.

Original deck by Otso Saariluoma. Tweaked to handle a little bit more
intercept.  I saw the idea on TWDA and since it featured two of my
favorite vampires I decided to try it out and loved the concept.
The concept is to get both Unmada and Scout Youngwood out, then recruit
your allies and call parity shifts and reckless agitations on your prey
to get him/her to villein/tap or otherwise empty his/her vampires. Then
you start playing your shattering crescendos. Slow to start, but gets
stronger as the game progresses. I used to have another Dreams of the
Sphinx in the deck but it seems I put it in another deck since I use
this primarily for fun. It turned out well, since it would have just
contested on every table. I also noticed that in three of the four games
I played I managed to slow the Ashur decks considerably since I always
offered to play Ashurs after my opponents finished their first cycle if
they would also do the same. However, I only have one master phase and
six ashurs to start with and if the opponents stick to the deal it hurts
them in the long run.

Deck Name: Brujah Debate 60 cards
Description: Deck based on Johannes Walch's Brujah Debate deck
he played during WoN in June. I added 3 cards to the original deck -
Jake, Carlton and Aranthebes. I would add Dreams of the Sphinx
instead of Cryptic Rider. Aranthebes wasn't useful but it would
help to contest it with my prey if he had played one.

This deck has some potencial, but in case your pred/prey is playing
a deck with fast setup if is very difficult to get VP's. If mid game
you should have 15+ pool and several minions striking for 3+. Smiling
Jack is a good option for late game when playing against two players.
Brujah Debate deck is very strong when played agains unexperienced
player who had never pleayed agains it before and there are lots of
them as Brujah Debate decks are not so common these days.

I will play that deck during a bigger tournament in the future.

Deck Name: Salmon Fishstick
Created by: Matt Morgan, based on Martin Major's deck
Description: It's rush combat with a strong master module. Master cards
are the best in the game. I'd always rather have too many than too few.
The name is because the final was won 2-1-1-1 and Fish and Stick lead the
way while Nana stayed hidden in my crypt. Fish is only in the deck to make
it count as a Guruhi deck for TWDA purposes.

-----------------------------------------

1x Bobby Lemon	4   ANI pro	 Gangrel:3
1x Dolie	3   abo ani	 Akunanse:4
1x Stick	3   ANI		 Nosferatu antitribu:4
1x Mouse	2   ani		 Nosferatu:3
1x Zip		2   ani		 Ravnos:3
1x Lisa Noble	1   ani		 Caitiff:3

/* One might wonder why only 4 Nana when she's the star? The answer is that
it's way better to have no Nana than all Nana. This deck needs a bunch of
minion actions to succeed */

Library (76)
Master [24]
2x Animalism

/* I really liked having AI here in the final, though I wound up not
playing it. Mbare Market probably isn't worth the slot. Should be a
2nd Fame, I think. Otherwise the masters worked out very well. */

Action [12]
10x Deep Song
1x Entrancement
1x Well-Marked

Equipment [1]
1x Ivory Bow

/* The Entrancement and Well-Marked didn't really earn their keep at any
point, though Well-Marked is typically a free action at least. I play
fewer Deep Songs than Martin's version because I'm not trying to rush
with every minion with every action. I bleed for 1 a little or stay up.
I want my prey to go forward. I don't want to simply squish him. Coming
out of the gate too fast is a mistake. */

Event [1]
1x Dragonbound

Reaction [6]
2x Cats' Guidance
1x Delaying Tactics
1x On the Qui Vive

/* Very few reactions. Sense the Savage Way should probably go since only
Nana can play them. I had multiple situations where I would have liked to
block with somebody else but couldn't because of the restriction on that
card. Getting to 2 intercept is nice, but it isn't worth the cost. */

Combat [32]

13x Carrion Crows
3x Target Vitals

it's not fun to run into other ANI decks, but them's the breaks. */

Deck Name: Balls of Stihl
Created by: Darby Keeney, based on a John Eno design.
Description: (Imbued Chainsaw Rush)

A couple of years ago, John stitched the Chainsaw rush into
a Dancing Imbued deck and the two of us tuned the deck into
the current state over a couple of months.

It is a bit more fragile than some of the intermediate builds
but is consistent. I considered adding Veil of Darkness and
the Rising, but opted to leave them out for this run.

My favorite moment of the tourament win with this deck was
bleeding with the Vagabound Mystic, who had successfully
equipped a Laptop Computer, IR Goggles, Leather Jacket and
the Heart of Nizchetus.

Deck Name: Shamblingi dla Zygi (Shamblings for Zyga)
Description: I've made that deck for my friend Zyga, who has recently sold
his collection. Unfortunatelly he was unable to play with us, so I decided
to try this deck out. That was the first time I had played a Gio Shambling
deck. It is based on Isak Esbjörnsson Bjärmark's "Sudario Hordes" deck with
some minor changes. I managed to win all three tables with 3GW and 10VP
in total. It's a nice - strong deck, but I'd add 2 x Adrea to bypass
+1 intercept blockers. Some Taget Vitals would be also vital in this deck.

2R+F
10 players
Darby Keeney

Deck Name: Govern is Weak Sauce
Based on/Inspired by: Original deck design.

Description: This deck tries to exploit a card I believed grossly
overpowered as early as the first glimpse - Brutal Influence.

In this tournament I don't think I ever got above 6 Orun on a single
vampire for various reasons (predator-based rush, cross table Sense
Dep, Pentex, contestation). Even at that modest level it's a
double-strength superior Govern the Unaligned and almost triple-strength
Govern bleed. Seems pretty good to me, despite the overhead.

The Banishment/Exile module is intended to eliminate bleed deflectors.
It also provides a great deal of flexibility to deal with other situations,
including players at the table whose pool management is entirely
recursion-based (e.g., Villein + Lilith's Blessing) or handling
players running 11/12-cap minions.

Deck Name: Pancake Mix

Description: Ever since cards like Reunion Kamut and Art of Memory
were printed, I have been wanting to build a deck with all these
Black Hand toys. I recently traded for enough Seraph's Seconds to
build a competitive Black Hand deck and try and get the most out
of them. I experimented with !Tremere and Lasombra for a bit at
first, before ending up with Assamites. Of course it should have
been obvious all along Assamites are the best pick for such a deck,
since they are the only clan that has two Seraphs in the same
grouping and get five different Black Hand crypt cards in that
same grouping.

This deck is a bloat/multiact deck at its core and, but with so
many actions a turn, it allows you keep pressure on your prey while
still bloating enough to survive even the most aggressive bleed
predators. It's especially important to build up a solid ready
region with at least a Seraph with a Tattoo Signal plus two other
vampires before you start throwing multiple Losses a turn at your
prey. Once the Watchtower comes into play even the most dedicated
wall decks will have trouble blocking every critical action and
you can oust everyone at your leisure.

Ashur/Liquidation based decks. //

to oust a particularly troublesome Henry Taylor twister deck, I used them
to recycle Haqim's Laws to stay alive against a !Ventrue bleeder without
a predator and I used them to get lot of mileage out of a single copy of
Loss. On top of it, you get to flush an unwanted card (say, extra
Information Highways or Gehenna Events) out of your hand. If I were
to play it again, I'd swap a Seraph's Second for a fifth Art of Memory. //

Deck Name: Homeland Recurred
Description:  The deck was a lot of fun, but it really needed
a lot of cycling.  The Recure the Homeland was the all start
with Burst of Sunlight and Target Vitals, it really did lots
of damage.  The trick of this deck is to tool up while bounding
bleeds forwards and backwards around the table, the My Enemies
Enemy are quite intentional, as this deck doesn't go forward
too hard, which means my prey gets going, taking table pressure
off my grand predator, I try to fix that here.  The allies and
Terrell Harding (wider view needs to be here) suck some blood off
as a means to stop deflections when you do lunge forward.
In round one after having 2 allies burned and my first vampire
with a vessel, blood doll, Ivory bow and Rutor's hand on turn 4,
I managed to lunge for 12 undeflected 4 turns later with the
Heidelberg, all the time just bouncing and tweaking blood off
vampires.  Society of Leopold takes a very close 2nd to all
star card, it really allowed me to stop other methheads as
needed.  This deck was something I tooled with on JOL, it
never did well and I rebuilt it the morning of the event,
it does have flow problems, so note if you play it, you will
be discarding every turn if you want a chance in hell.  Truth
be told, my win came from luck, and my ability to capitalize
on it.  The last bit of advice, ditch the harvest rites, trust
me, they suck here.  Thanks to Jay for getting such a large
showing from Columbus and to the Newark crew for making it out!

Deck Name: Armin Hammer
Description:
The deck plays generally the same as any stealth/vote deck with a more
interesting stealth module. Ideally Armin Brenner is your first
minion and should always be first unless he isn't in your opening
crypt. He is the only minion in the crypt that can maximize the use
of all cards in the crypt and his 1 pool/vote adds up over the course
of the game. The deck will play quite a few cards each turn and
maximizing cards like Forced March for stealth and untap is key.

The deck can generally bloat fast enough to handle a moderately fast
bleeding predator and Majesty or Resist Earth's Grasp will slow down
Animalism rush significantly while accepting that a Grappling foe will
kill the deck. Undele is key for late game antics to make sure your
two other actions/turn are exactly what you want them to be.

While it never showed, gaining potentially 5 pool calling a Black
Forest Base action is rather nice. The changes I would make after
playing it outside of the local playgroup would be two fewer KRCs and
another Neonate Breach and then some other damage vote or maybe even
a utility vote like Snipe Hunt/Permanent Vacation to take out late
threats that can be brought back. Delaying Tactics recycled in the
finals against me slowed down my offense several turns.

Guruhi Are the Land
Newark, Ohio
March 8th 2011
2R+F
19 players
John Bell

-- 2gw8 (1st seed)

Deck Name: He Has To Run Out Sometime...
Description:
The deck is so named because every game I have played it, someone at the table
has commented that I would have to run out of Faerie Wards at some point. Until
it's seen in action, it is hard to describe just how effective a wall this deck
can be without blocking at all. The deck is extremely slow, but relies on
locking down its predator to get itself entrenched. Eternal Vigilance really
makes the deck obnoxious - it does require you to block, but judicious usage can
truly sap your predator's will - attempt to block a hunt or vote without
intercept or ensure that you have an Obedience in hand for 0-stealth actions.
The Rack and Papillion for Marconius assure that you can Faerie Wards to your
heart's content and Smiling Jack to end games. The major challenge for the deck
is increasing Marconius' capacity to ensure everyone is a legal target for
Faerie Wards/Banishment.

Crypt (12 cards, min=30, max=38, avg=8.67)
------------------------------------------
5x Marconius	    9	DOM MYT OBT pot		archbishop  Kiasyd:2 -- Paying 1 less for Faerie Wards is what makes the deck viable in the first place.
2x Marcus Vitel	    10	DOM FOR OBF OBT PRE	prince	    Ventrue:3 -- Conditional +bleed for everyone else in the crypt, but I rarely have more than 2 vampires out. His inclusion is a bit questionable to me at this point.
2x Quentin	    9	AUS DOM FOR cel obt	bishop	    Ventrue antitribu:2 -- I've considered adding more of Quentin since voting is one of the weaknesses of the deck (Faerie Wards only usable on [D] actions). His ability to cancel votes has been critical several games.
2x Gratiano	    8	DOM OBT obf pot		priscus	    Lasombra:2 -- He's just good for this deck in every way.
1x Béatrice L'Angou 5	MYT aus dom nec			    Kiasyd:2 -- probably should change her to someone more useful.

probably be some Govern's in this deck to utilize all the wonderful superior

Deck name: A Twist of Madness
Created by: Christian Nislev (all credit goes to to Ben Peal and Keith Page of course...)

Description: The classic Henry Taylor-twister deck where Henry ends up
blocking everything and ousting with Smiling Jack. I felt the deck was
a bit too passive, so added Clan Impersonation and Madness Network
which allows for some serious end game bleed punch with Anima
Gathering and Earth Control stealth. Bleeding at the end of your
predator's turn gives you the edge and a pool which pays for Jack. 31
cards is too much, but there's some nifty mechanics that adds
flexibility to the classic deck.

Deck Name: Der Räuber und der Prinz
Description: First combat is to cycle in to necessary cards, both in
graveyard and in hand.  After that play Ashurs and recycle the necessary
cards back into library and deck.  Always keep in mind the amount of
ashurs in the deck so that you don't choke on masters.

-- 5vp in final

Deck Name: All You Need Is Oust
Description:
The deck is straight forward offense. The only action in the deck that
doesn't have any offensive potential is Carlton Van Wyck which I threw
in last minute. Get out 2 vampires and try to bleed, vote and recruit
with them each turn. The first action is usually the most important
and has the Uncontrolled Impulse to push it through. Majesty and
change of target gets through and defenders until you can get your
actions through. Decent pool gain to slow down your predator. If you
are in a really bad spot, bloat and vote upstream. Don't bother
leaving any vampires for blocking unless you don't have any actions
left, or you are looking at static intercept combat with no modifiers
to push your actions through.

Deck Name: The new A
Description: Classic Triple A concept enhanced with the new big A, Ashur Tablets.

The only change I would make in this deck is to add an Anarchist Uprising
and an Archon (look, more A's!) and cut out a Perpetual Care and a Psyche.
I had not realized Alastor doesn't allow you to rush allies and that was
mighty annoying in two of the four games.

The two cards that got my the win today were Metro Underground (having
an untapped Assault Rifle is *huge*) and the Entrancement, that I could
play unblockable in the finals to steal a Nephandus, bring it back to
my hand with Ashur's the next turn and steal another Nephandus.

Powerbase: Los Angeles Event #1
Strategicon - GAMEX 2010, Los Angeles, California
May 29th 2010
2R+F
12 players
Darby Keeney

Deck Name: [2010 TW] The World's Biggest Small Multirushers

Comments:  Many thanks to Fred Scott for lending me 2 Tupdogs for this
tournament.   Generally, I have found a 2.5:1 Tupdog-to-!Tremere ratio
to work out pretty well, though a long string of Dogs at the top pf
one's crypt is frustrating.

The objective for this deck is to get additional mileage from the
Tupdogs...decreasing their effective cost from 1 pool per action to
0.5 pool per action and further leveraging both the rush and the slave
option (rush first, untap, available for slave clause, take an action
of the slave clause is not needed).

The deck is supposed to carry 1 more Ashur Tablet, but I seem to own
only 5 at this time.  4, 6 or 7 seem like the right numbers to me,
depending on your risk tolerance and recycling needs.

Synergies:
Carver's + Dragonbound and Carver's + Vessel are pretty clear.
Carver's + Raw Recruit is an indefinate hold on a Recruit target (that
could not be Graverobbed).  Carver's not affecting Tupdogs is a bonus.

Heidleburg can save master vampires from dangerous hunting
requirements, can empty a Tupdog of before it explodes and allows 2
Hand of Conrad actions per turn.

Deck Name: Lawyers, Guns and Money
Description:
This is my attempt to make a Ventrue version of the !Ventrue
intercept/combat deck I've been playing, because the new law firm has
such an excellent crypt. Most of the card choices here seem pretty
obvious, but I'll attempt some Morganesque deck commentary for those
that might seem odd or should be changed.

Crypt (12 cards, min=19, max=36, avg=6.92)
------------------------------------------
3x Lodin (Olaf Holte)	8   DOM FOR PRE aus pro		prince	  Ventrue:5
2x Mary Anne Blaire	10  AUS DOM FOR PRE ani pot	justicar  Ventrue:5
2x Graham Gottesman	7   DOM FOR obf pre tha		prince	  Ventrue:5
2x Mustafa, The Heir	6   FOR PRE cel dom		prince	  Ventrue:4
1x Jephta Hester	5   DOM FOR aus				  Ventrue antitribu:4
1x João Bilé		5   DOM FOR pre				  Ventrue:4
1x Ulrike Rothbart	3   dom for				  Ventrue antitribu:4

/* In theory, Mary Anne Blaire is great for this deck. In practice, I think she's
probably too big and should be changed into another Graham and a
smaller vampire. Emily Carson would be a good choice. */

Library (80)
Master [14]
2x Anarch Troublemaker
4x Blood Doll
1x Ephor
1x Island of Yiaros

/* I really want his card to be good, and this would seem to be the
deck for it to shine. I don't think I've ever actually played it in
the year or so that I've been working on this deck, though, so that's
probably a pretty good sign that it could be usefully replaced. */

1x KRCG News Radio
1x Papillon
1x Pentex(TM) Subversion
1x Smiling Jack, The Anarch
1x Ventrue Headquarters
1x WMRH Talk Radio

/* Absolutely no idea why there isn't a Giant's Blood in here,
particularly since I put that card into just about every deck I make.
The Island will definitely be changed out for one in the future. */

Action [9]
1x Aranthebes, The Immortal
5x Govern the Unaligned
3x Scouting Mission

/* The idea here was that using Scouting Mission over more Governs
would save me blood. In practice, they should all be Governs. */

Action Modifier [6]
1x Foreshadowing Destruction
4x Freak Drive
1x Threats

/* This needs more bleed punch, and the free cards can probably be
safely changed into Conditioning without worrying about its blood
cost. During the tournament, I kept wondering why I was drawing so few
bleed modifiers. More evidence that you should be very familiar with a
deck before you play it in a rated event... */

Ally [1]
1x Carlton Van Wyk (Hunter)

Combat [25]
4x Hidden Strength
3x Indomitability
5x Resilience
4x Rolling with the Punches
2x Taste of Vitae
2x Unflinching Persistence
5x Weighted Walking Stick

/* Too much damage prevention. During all four games of the tournament,
there were times when I found myself looking at three or four combat
cards and wishing that they were anything else. Matt Hirsch took a
great picture of my hand during round three, in which you see six
damage prevention cards and a Walking Stick. Ouch. Some of this will
be taken out for more bleed mods. */

Equipment [4]
1x Bowl of Convergence

/* If Mary Anne doesn't appear in the crypt any more, this card
obviously needs to be changed into a Sport Bike. */

1x Palatial Estate

/* I still haven't figured out if Palatial Estate is ever worth the
action or card slot. I think math is against me on this one, but I'll
leave it here until I can decide definitively. */

2x Sawed-Off Shotgun

/* People will probably mock me for the Shotguns again, but they've
never done wrong by me. */

Political Action [2]
2x Banishment

/* Another "in theory this is great" card, particularly for lockdown
during the two-player game. Probably one or both should be more
straightforward offensive votes like Anarchist Uprising or KRC. */

Reaction [18]
8x Deflection
2x On the Qui Vive
8x Second Tradition: Domain

/* Enough wake tech to make Peal grumpy during the finals when he was
trying to oust me, so it must be just the right amount. */

Retainer [1]
1x Mr. Winthrop

Crypt (12 cards, min=18, max=36, avg=6.83)
------------------------------------------
5x Casino Reeds			9   ANI OBF POT cel dem	 prince	 Nosferatu:3
2x Nikolaus Vermeulen		7   POT ani for obf	 prince	 Nosferatu:2
1x Amelia, The Blood Red Tears	5   POT ani obf		 	 Nosferatu:3
1x Calebros, The Martyr		5   ANI obf pot		 prince	 Nosferatu:2
1x Nigel the Shunned		5   ANI POT obf		 	 Nosferatu antitribu:2
1x Agatha			4   POT obf		 	 Nosferatu antitribu:2
1x Jimmy Dunn			4   CEL POT for		 	 Pander:2

/* A fairly self-explanatory crypt. My primary concern was to get POT on everybody
so that they can fling superior gates. Calebros is the one exception, but he is
well worth it for ANI and a prince title. */

Library (90)
Action (4)
1x Army of Rats
2x Deep Song
1x SchreckNET

/* I've never been able to tap SchreckNET, but it's an easy action to cycle.
Some day, I'll probably get to use it. */

Action Modifier/Combat (5)
5x Swallowed by the Night

/* These are often very useful as stealth for early game set up actions,
especially Casino's 0 stealth action to move blood. Given how often I
use them at basic, it might be wise to swap a couple for Lost in Crowds. */

Combat (36)
2x Canine Horde
7x Carrion Crows
2x Flash
2x Flesh Bond
6x Pack Alpha
2x Target Vitals
2x Taste of Vitae
13x Thrown Gate

/* The beauty of this combat package is its consistency, coupled with the ability
to surprisingly divert from the playbook. I have been able to shut down some
very nasty combat decks simply by always having a gate to manuever and do some
damage, and then by surprisingly ending combat or dodging (there used to be some
Behind You, and it could go back in) when I got caught in a bind. Flesh Bond
is great for its flexibility, as it deals 3R damage with Casino's special. */

Equipment (2)
2x Camera Phone

/* These tend to go on the support minions, not on Casino. They really help
get the oust in once I've crippled my prey's minions */

Master (14)
4x Blood Doll
1x Fame
1x Giant's Blood
4x Haven Uncovered
1x Pentex(TM) Subversion
1x Rack, The
1x Smiling Jack, The Anarch
1x Sudden Reversal

/* A previous version of this deck, which got me to a final at Origins,
spent a total of 0 pool on library card costs. I added a Pentex Subversion
because it is awesome, and to contest should one land on Casino. (I would
still prefer that it be banned.) Spending so little pool is a major part
of what makes this deck work. Casino and Nikolaus both help get Nosferatu
at reduced prices, and I never bring out more than 4 vampires. Usually I
stick with 3, or even 2 under severe  pressure. I use the extra pool as a
buffer because at some point in the game I need to tap out against my prey,
and then wake several times to stop her recovery actions. A lot of wall deck
players seem to imagine that they can do this and magically cycle into the
right mix of combat and reactions. Usually that won't happen. However, by
keeping my pool as high as possible, I can afford to take some serious hits
from my predator while I turn my defense into offense. */

Reaction (22)
4x Cats' Guidance
4x On the Qui Vive
1x Rat's Warning
6x Second Tradition: Domain
7x Sense the Savage Way

/* I would certainly entertain the possibility of cutting some STSW
for more 2nd Traditions. */

Retainer (7)
7x Raven Spy

Sixth Tradition: Destruction
Berkeley, California
December 20th 2009
2R+F
10 players
Ira Fay

Desk: Beasts on the plains, twirling their canes
Description: This desk is inspired by Hugh Angseesing's
deck (and others) of similar name.  I wanted to see if I
could make the fortitude combat + WWS work for Akunanse.
Since the bleed offense is obviously weaker without dom,
and because I wanted to use freak drive and have 2 useful
actions for each minion, I added votes, which worked
pretty well.  No Secrets is strong, but I was afraid of
Pentex, so I wanted to play a deck that had a reasonable
chance of getting out 2 Magaji.  Also, using the Matt
Morgan school of thought, I wanted to have some good
non-threatening building actions early-game, while my prey
weakens my grand-prey.  Wise Spider and Owl Companion are
great for that.  This deck has limited untaps, but
canceling bounces with Terra Incognita requires only one
untapped minion, which was pretty easy given Wise Spider
or influencing out a new minion.

a try. You might consider this deck as a mix between Vicent Ripoll EC
TWD and Ruben Feldman's "Vignes" deck. I decided to play with auspex

Deck Name: Tutte bjuder till fest
Description: The deck is best slow-played, not to show off too much
dominate to keep the table guessing at whether you play combat or
votes. Using mirror walk and obedience to never get into a combat you
don't want to enter. Just wait the game out and take the last two VPs
before anyone knows what's happening (at least that's the idea ^_^).
Works really well in a combat environment, would probably be weak
against vote decks with stealth - but thankfully I never had to face
that.

Deck Name: Cogwork Brussels
Description: The deck is a Nosferatu multi-action toolbox with an
emphasis on bleeding. The foundation of the deck is Cock Robin's
special ability to untap after a successful action requiring
Animalism. Also Baron Dieudonne can untap after a successful action
(but only by paying a blood). Another untap possibility is provided by
Warsaw Station. With Tier of Souls, Deep Song and eventually Enkil Cog
the deck has considerable bleed potential. Thanks to Preternatural
Strength you only need to make room for few extra combat cards to be
very effective in combat, while being able to do "defensive rushing"
with Deep Song.
Maybe the deck's biggest advantage in a tournament is that other
players tend to underestimate its bleed potential and in general have
trouble assessing the deck's capabilities.

specific rush defense, may play delaying tactics, and in the ash-heap

uncontrolled region, especially if you don't have Lumumba or all 4

the Abombwe's on 4-caps, so you can get them up to 5 for Ancestor
Spirit, or a bigger voter cap.  Voter cap with Lumumba, since that's
the only vamp with PRE (if you get out 6 vamps, you have a ~76% chance
of getting Lumumba.)

Vincent Ripoll (Ankha)

Deck Name: Aim and Chain
Description: An easy to play bruise'n'bleed deck. Get out the 5-caps,
Govern down on the small ones, you should quickly have 5 vamps out
with dom and for and plenty (about 20) pools left. Bleed steadily,
even for 1, and use the magic of the Target Vitals to maim the
blockers.
It resists quite well (surprisingly, but that's the magic of TV)
against real fight decks.
It entered the final at the third place and made GW4 during the final
between a palla embrace deck (predator) and a !Malk BS (prey).
There is an alternate crypt in group 4-5 but it uses higher caps and
is therefore too slow.

been playing for years.  The primary function is stealth/bleed, but it
has a few non-stealth options like Anarch Troublemakers and
Seduction.  The biggest change I made for this particular variant was
going for group 3/4 instead of group 2/3.   The g3/4 crypt is
definitely weaker on votes but has a somewhat better selection of obt/
dom mid-caps.

Deck Name: The wall that is not really a wall

This deck originally started as mono Auspex deck with guns and Black
Hand-tech for bloating purposes, but evolved into something that can
actually oust players as well. The gameplan is to feign being a bleed
deck that's not drawing into its payload while bloating enough to bring
out a few minions and equip one or two Magnums. Once you feel you're
pretty safe from your predator, start actively blocking your prey's
minions with Eagle's Sight and bleed hard into him. Once you have
secured a VP just bloat and block some more and be the last man
standing for the 3VP game win.

Taste of Vitae is vital to keep your bloat going and the Target Vitals
act a nasty surprise that deters combat decks from picking a fight with
you. It can also be used to knock out a weakened minion or put a rather
painful dent into a War Ghoul or some other ally. Other than that it's
really just a wall with a healthy amount of stealth bleed to go with it.

Celestial Harmony #2
Eudemonia, Berkeley, California
June 22nd 2008
10 players
Ira Fay

Deck Name: Lots of Babies

Description: It's a little tricky to acquire 30 Trophy: Progeny irl
(thanks gNat and Ian!), but once you get them, this deck can be fun to
play.  It reliably takes advantage of turns 1-3 master phases, which
are often wasted in most decks.  Miller's special is incredibly good -
he is so perfect for this deck, and Anson compliments him
beautifully.  My goal in designing this deck was to get a trophy deck
in the TWDA, and assuming I didn't make any stupid illegal deck
errors, I'm excited to post the first one.  Trophy: Progeny is very
powerful in such large numbers, especially because it can act that
same turn.  Choosing the right Red List target is tricky, because you
want something that you can burn, but other players can't.  Whenever
possible, choose a target that your prey controls.  Then, just sit
back and wait as long as possible, building the perfect combat hand,
holding the Palle Grande, playing 2-3 Trophies per turn.  Try to
convince the table that you're not a threat (much easier when the
Palla Grande is in your hand, and not on the table.)  If things are
flowing smoothly, you'll have 10+ Trophies on the table by turn ~8,
and then you can lunge when you're ready.  If you have a fast
predator, bring up Anson first because he can Deflect, Parity Shift,
and 2nd Trad to keep you in the game.  If you draw The Parthenon
early, you can consider bringing up Miller first.  Without The
Parthenon, you'll hand jam on Masters.  It's very rare that I discard
a Trophy: Progeny in this deck.  Golconda was very helpful to keep me
(or an ally) in the game long enough for the combo to go off.

As I write this up I notice I have 88 cards instead of 90, and since I
was decked 2 of my 3 games I should probably address this! Blood
management can be an issue and getting off a well-timed Festivo 2 of
the 3 games was key. Mind Rape was less useful than I
anticipated...probably better off with Scouting Missions to increase
my crypt-machine mechanism early in the game. Deep Cover Agent is
handy when I remember to actually use it! Card flow is handled with
Heart and the 3 Dreams, but there were a couple of times I had to play
through some ugly clumping. A few more permanents are probably in
order, particularly Guarded Rubrics and a weapon or two.

Deck name: Along comes the spider
Description: This deck won the mini qualifier in Torun, a local
tournament in Warsaw, and managed to get into the final round during
the Polish ECQ.  it's a very solid deck against most archetypes, card
flow is really impressive, and it does tend to be underestimated (not
too often, but it happens).  it's also a very fun deck to play, in the
ideal setup you block out your predator while making constant pressure
on your prey.

/* Set's Curse was originally Far Mastery, but more of my crypt can play
Set's Curse and there are more available targets.  In round 1, I was a
little slow with it and Meno Ngari got a skill card before I could hit
him with it.  In round 2, I turned Lupo into a snake, which was really
cool, even if it probably didn't cause me to win any more than I was
already winning.  I died too quickly to make use of it in round 3, but
turning one of Ben Peal's War Ghouls into a snake would've been pretty
great.  There were small vampires that would've made good targets for
this in the final, but sadly I had nobody with SER to play it, so it
had to be discarded.

10x Spell of Life was pretty good in a 61 card deck.  I normally got
the Spell off around turn 7 or so, I think.  I never tried to get it to
happen again and never needed it.  Each game concluded a turn or two
after I completed the Spell (or in the case of round 3, the game
concluded for me the turn before I would've completed it). */

Deck Name: Howling Anarchs
Description: Continuing in my quest to with a tournament with
every clan alphabetically, I had to put together an Ahrimanes
deck.  I hadn't ever played them much and generally felt like
they were a decent clan, but Howler always goes to torpor, so
that's a pretty major liability.  I asked for some advice on
the #vtes irc chat and eventually jhattara gave me the idea of
playing your traditional blocking felines with some Anarch Revolts
to speed the table up.  Great idea!  Still not having much experience
with Ahrmanes, I basically copied David Quinonero's famous deck
and shoehorned some Anarch Revolts.  It turned out pretty well,
if a little slow.  I won my first round by the skin of my teeth
and had to settle for a 2-2 split in the 2nd as my prey sort of
ran away with the table.  The deck was ideal for the more
deliberately-played final and I won with 2.5VP.

Crypt (12 cards, min=12, max=32, avg=5.75)
------------------------------------------
4x Howler	    8	ANI PRE SPI obf		Ahrimane:2
2x Siamese, The	    7	PRE SPI ani pro		Ahrimane:2
1x Cynthia Ingold   6	SPI ani for pre		Ahrimane:2
1x Nettie Hale	    5	ani cel pre pro spi	Ahrimane:2
1x Bobby Lemon	    4	ANI pro			Gangrel:3
1x Juanita Santiago 4	ani pre spi		Ahrimane:2
1x Dani		    2	ani			Nosferatu antitribu:2
1x Gillian Krader   2	ani dem			Pander:2

/* I decided to throw a couple small guys in, but in general
they weren't super helpful.  The deck is basically Howler
with maybe The Siamese or Cynthia filling in if Howler is
unwilling or unable to perform her duties. */

Library (90)
Master [19]
1x Anarch Free Press, The
/* Not free and doesn't provide a press.  Can we get some
errata?  The one time I tried to play this it was Suddened. */
4x Anarch Revolt
1x Animalism
2x Direct Intervention
1x Fame
1x Giant's Blood
1x Guardian Angel
1x Rack, The
1x Seattle Committee
1x Smiling Jack, The Anarch
5x Vessel

/* The Anarch Revolts and Fame were responsible for both my
game wins.  I think I nailed a couple Blood Dolls with Vessels,
but I mostly included them over Blood Dolls because I was
worried about master hand jam. */

Action [11]
1x Aranthebes, The Immortal
6x Enchant Kindred
4x Nose of the Hound

/* Didn't need Aranthebes because of a lack of weenie predators.
I mostly played the Enchant Kindreds at inferior, so they might've
been better bleed cards (Legal, Social, Entrancement?).  4x Nose
of the Hound was pretty nice. */

Combat/Action Modifier [5]
5x Swiftness of the Stag

/* Okay, so I actually got my firsts ousts in the games I
won by bleeding for 2 at 1 stealth, but I like to think the
Anarch Revolts and Fame are what got me there.  These were
pretty good for keeping things up close and personal with
Flash Harrison. */

Equipment [1]
1x Flak Jacket

/* Never when I needed it.  Sigh.  Same with the Guardian Angel. */

Event [1]
1x Dragonbound

/* This was mostly only good for backousting Jesse when he
wouldn't let Howler out of a Pentex. */

Reaction [22]
4x Cats' Guidance
4x Falcon's Eye
3x On the Qui Vive
3x Sense the Savage Way
8x Speak with Spirits

/* I nearly lost the first game because I just couldn't draw
any untap or intercept and my prey was getting away with murder
for it.  It's weird because this looks like plenty to me. */

Retainer [11]
6x Murder of Crows
1x Owl Companion
4x Raven Spy

/* The Murders are pretty good here in that they make up for
the fact that the support crew have inferior Animalism (not
too scary on its own) and let Howler save on blood by doing
a good amount of damage from long range. */

Combat [20]
5x Aid from Bats
2x Canine Horde
3x Carrion Crows
8x Pack Alpha
2x Taste of Vitae

/* Pretty light combat package, especially since 8 of those
cards don't actually do anything to hurt the opponent or
protect my minion.  The deck obviously relies heavily on
Howler's natural abilities and whatever permanents it can
put together.  Some Leapfrog or Majesty or something might've
been good, but I didn't feel like there was room for it
and it was more important to be able to hurt opposing minions. */

Matt's comments on the final:

It didn't work the way it was intended to in the finals. In retrospect
I should have brought out Demdemeh instead of Wamukota as my second
vampire, but I thought his ability would be important for my retain
actions(it was never used). I never could get enough pool to bring
out Demdemeh afterwards. A herd of elephants would have greatly
increased my ousting ability.

It is nice to know that the deck can survive without all of the "A"
team in play.

Lords of the Night is Legal!
Indianapolis, Indiana
October 28th 2007
3R+F
15 players
Ankur Gupta

Deck Name:	Black Hand CEL
Description:	The deck is yet another testament to my love for Black
Hand, even without using the neat new cards of wonderfulness for Black Hand.
This deck focuses on attrition using Zip Guns/Blur/Taste. Let's
be honest: Zip Guns are not the most wonderful weapon ever,
but the idea is to simply survive combat until the end game.
Then, maneuvers are extremely powerful, and selective torporing
will balance the table into a win. There is a subtle but
important blood denial strategy that I feel stays nicely under
the radar. Generally the tables were unaware of the danger
until it was too late. Thuggees, Vampiric Disease, Restricted
Vitae, Strained Vitae Supply, Vessel, and moderate combat all
work well together to present a solid package for that purpose.
My own worries are handled by Zip Guns (to avoid disease),
Weeping Stone, and Corporeal Reservoirs.

Special mention of Vampiric Disease: it was a key card to victory
in both the final and two rounds beforehand. I love Vessel; it
should have a big impact once people forget about vessel and
play more blood dolls again.

The deck definitely carries weaknesses against animalism combat
or bigger guns. You have to make sure that you handle these
decks by talking them off the table or targeting their weakness.
For larger guns, pool is often a problem. Hone in on that. For
decks with animalism, there is a limit to how many times they
can repeat their schtick. Focus on killing one guy at a time.
With +2/+3 intercept plus permanents, you should be able to
manage it. Your "defense" against combat ends is that no one
is hurting you. That's benefit enough. Eventually they will run
out and they will be low on blood to boot. And if you get that
Vampiric Disease. . . . .

I would totally cut the single Art of Memory for a Reunion Kamut.
I just couldn't find one at the time.

NAC 2007 Day 2
Los Angeles, California
September 23rd 2007
3R+F
36 players
Ben Peal

-- 4vp in final

Deck Name: Angellore (Live In LA)
Description:
This is a modified version of the deck I used to win the 2007 Origins
qualifier. I chose this version of breed-boon for the 2007 NAC (and
EC) because of its anti-ally capabilities, its combat defense, its
surprise lunge capability, and its strong vote lock/push. I dropped
the 2 Enchant Kindred in favor of more Entrancements and another
Direct Intervention. I changed a Consanguineous Boon into an
Autarkis Persecution and 2 Kine Resources Contested into 2
Conservative Agitations as a defense against Delaying Tactics. I
dropped the 2 Change of Target and the 1 Crusade: Philadelphia
since I wasn't getting much use out of them. In their place, I added
an event package of Absimiliard's Army, Break the Code, and The
Uncoiling. Absimiliard's Army isn't in there for the synergy with
Entrancement (though it's nice), but is instead intended as a defense
against rush combat. This paid off in Round 2 of the 2007 NAC,
when I had Norm Brown's Basilia deck as a predator. Again, Siren's
Lure is a devastating card. It can change a run of the mill "bleed
for 1 to get the edge" turn into an ousting lunge. To answer a
frequently-asked question, I don't use Ensemble because it's just
asking to be bounced, leaving me to spend the next turn hunting with
everyone.

Break the Code

This deck was designed to take advantage of the usual championship
day one desperation.  I was disappointed when I had no stealth/bleed
predators in any of my preliminary rounds.  I was able to bounce
some large, stealthy bleeds in the final.  That allowed me to oust
my first prey.  I then won a long, thought out, heads up duel against
Pete Oh's triple A deck. Thanks to those who organized, played in,
and judged this tournament.

Jay Kristoff,
V:EKN Prince of Columbus, Ohio USA

In theory, this fat Pander deck taps people with various
special abilities and Majesty's and supposedly does pool
damage.  In practice, bounce is pretty good, especially
with evasion bleed as predator (prelim round), and hanging
around accidentally results in VPs (finals).

"This deck looks tame out of the gate and seemed to have
it's trouble aganst my AUS intercept deck. But I stood
corrected as I faced this menace in the final only to fall
helplessly as his predator to the floor. I was amazing at
the glorious victory he pulled out in the final seconds of
the match to crush the Lasombra." - Mike Courtois

Cape Town, South Africa
August 11th 2007
14 players
Roberta Crumplin

Deck Name: The Slow Withering
Description:
When I built this deck I had in mind something that could righteously
stop vampires, that could interfere with their hunting in particular
and with their actions generally. The intercept generated by Second
Sight and by The Unmasking, coupled with Discern and Sport's Bike,
is generally enough to really hamper a Methuselah's plans. Add to that
Determine and Champion and you really start to piss other players off.
The trick is, though, to apply it all in such a fashion that you don't
end up turning the whole table against you - crucial when you're trying
to bring out a hefty ten event cards that restrict all other players on
the table, except of course yourself, and those few other Imbued players
out there. Once those event cards start hitting the table it is very hard
for Methuselah's to generate the same kind of staying power that an
Imbued deck can muster. Add to that some bleed, and some fight, and
the deck can pretty much wear down anything. It's not to say that the
deck doesn't have it's weaknesses, or that it can't be taken down, it
most certainly can, but they are weaknesses for other players to discover
and, in my favour, of course, is the fact that the Imbued still remain
relatively understudied by most.

Writ of Acceptance
Boston, Massachusetts
June 24th 2007
3R+F
10 players
D.J. Chagnon (Meej)

-- 4vp in final

Deck Name: Darby Dance of the Seven Veils

An adaptation of various Darby Dance decks, particularly John
Newquist's 12/17/06 Razorbat: Atlanta winner (at least, that was the
one that I saw a bunch of this tech in), modified to adapt to Boston's
heavy-intercept typical metagame - one-stealth actions just rarely cut
it, and 2 stealth sometimes isn't enough - by bolting in some OBF
vampires into the crypt for Cloaks, Veils, and some blood-doll bloat.
Also solves the problems of the classic Imbued vulnerability to
Smiling Jack, Reins of Power, Ancient Influence, etc., at the cost of
a little less reliability in the crypt, which bit me once badly in the
3rd round (all 4 vampires out of 5 crypt cards looked at).While I
can't claim credit for much of the deck-manipulating innovation, Luc
is just plain GOLD - the +3 hand-size action works great as an end-of-
the-turn action to set up your hand for next turn.  I think I'm going
to switch out Jeffrey Mullins for a second Luc.
